Scientists said Thursday that they had trained a bacterium to eat and grow on a diet of arsenic, in place of phosphorus — one of six elements considered essential for life — opening up the possibility that organisms could exist elsewhere in the universe or even here on Earth using biochemical powers we have not yet dared to dream about.
 
 The bacterium, scraped from the bottom of Mono Lake in California and grown for months in a lab mixture containing arsenic, gradually swapped out atoms of phosphorus in its little body for atoms of arsenic.
 
 Scientists said the results, if confirmed, would expand the notion of what life could be and where it could be. “There is basic mystery, when you look at life,” said Dimitar Sasselov, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics and director of an institute on the origins of life there, who was not involved in the work. “Nature only uses a restrictive set of molecules and chemical reactions out of many thousands available. This is our first glimmer that maybe there are other options.”

 Anyway, so here’s the gist:
 
 - The bacteria are able to substitute arsenic into their DNA and proteins in the place of phosphorous. This shatters the notion of C, H, O, N, S, P being the only six elements that Earth life is based on. But they don’t depend on arsenic, and can actually use phosphorus, too.
 
 - These bacteria are not a new branch of life, but are related to the same ones eating Gulf of Mexico oil as we speak. There is (as of yet) no secret biosphere of independent evolution on Earth. But independent evolution in a previously-termed “toxic environment” is always neat.
 
 - The arsenic fed to these bugs was incorporated in the DNA, proteins, fats, everywhere. They seem to cope with the unstable nature of the element quite well, and make it a critical part of their metabolism.
 
 So it isn’t aliens. We knew that. But I think it is still immensely exciting. It changes the notion of what we should be looking for in a habitable environment for extraterrestrial life. It’s a reminder to think about what is possible, not only what we know to exist.
 
 The implications for new biochemical pathways, synthetic biology and evolution are still huge, and the fact that this isn’t aliens or anything like that shouldn’t stop anyone from being excited to all get-out.

Why are atoms separable into oppositely charged particles? Indeed, when it comes right down to it: Why is there something, rather than nothing?
 
 I don't know. I'm perfectly comfortable accepting that some things are just brute facts, and we can't dig any deeper in terms of rational justification. There are limits. On the other hand, I don't think that this sort of skepticism is itself anything more than a subjective opinion.
 
 I remember reading a discussion between Richard Dawkins and a physicist once (sorry, I long ago lost the link). Like Dawkins, the physicist was an atheist, but he didn't share Dawkins view of religion. Anyway, to make a long story short, the physicist raised that "ultimate question" of Why something, not nothing? And Dawkins' response really struck me: he said, 'But why is that even an interesting question?' I remember thinking, since when is "interesting" a scientific category, or even an objective category at all?
 
 Don't get me wrong. I don't find the question particularly interesting myself. That's partly because, like all metaphysical questions, I don't think it admits of any objective answers anyway. But of course, that's just my subjective assessment. I could be wrong, and even if I'm not, if it's a question that other people find subjectively worth asking, I don't think they're unreasonable for asking it. (They might be unreasonable depending on how they answer it, as are Biblical literalists, for example.)
 
 In fact, there might even be a good evolutionary reason why we ask such questions. We are, as Aristotle put it, rational animals. We look for reasons -- and not just mechanically, but purposively. There is some evidence, if I recall, that very young children think of nearly everything in terms of a "who." It's why cartoons can so easily personify inanimate objects. I don't mean this to be an insult to religious persons: I don't think faith is ipso facto infantile. What I'm trying to say is, there is a deep-seated tendency for us to look at the world around us in terms of meaning and purpose. It's probably a product of evolving to cope with our exceedingly complex social organization. And in this sense, wondering if there is meaning purpose beyond just the world of human interactions is just an extension of something our brains naturally do anyway.

 Part of the difficulty here has to do with the way that "God" or "the universe" are conceptualized in the first place. As traditionally conceived, God doesn't possess any of the properties of empirical objects, like a divisible body. This latter is necessary for coming to be and passing away: the composition and then decomposition of a being. Since he doesn't get composed or decomposed, God simply is, without reference to temporal processes. (That's what "eternal" means: not always and forever, but literally outside time altogether.) God has being in the eternal present, without past or future. By contrast, the universe, as a natural object, can come to be and pass away.
 
 Now maybe this isn't a very satisfying answer, on a number of levels. Personally, I'm inclined to think that anythign completely lacking in empirical, spatio-temporal qualities isn't merely transcendent: it isn't, in any meaningful sense. And I don't know what sense it makes, given modern physics, to say that the universe had a beginning in time, since the origins of the universe are now wrapped up with the origins of time and space themselves. But regardless, it seems like when it comes to "God" and "the universe," we're dealing with two pretty different sorts of entities.

silicon-based life
In 1891, the German astrophysicist Julius Scheiner became perhaps the first person to speculate on the suitability of silicon as a basis for life. This idea was taken up by the British chemist James Emerson Reynolds who, in 1893, in his opening address to the British Association for the Advancement of Science, pointed out that the heat stability of silicon compounds might allow life to exist at very high temperatures (see thermophiles). In an 1894 article, drawing on Reynolds's ideas and also those of Robert Ball, H. G. Wells wrote:
 
 
One is startled towards fantastic imaginings by such a suggestion: visions of silicon-aluminium organisms – why not silicon-aluminium men at once? – wandering through an atmosphere of gaseous sulphur, let us say, by the shores of a sea of liquid iron some thousand degrees or so above the temperature of a blast furnace. 

 
 Thirty years later, J. B. S. Haldane suggested that life might be found deep inside a planet based on partly molten silicates, the oxidation of iron perhaps providing it with energy.
 
 Silicon biochemistry?
 
 At first sight, silicon does look like a promising organic alternative to carbon. It is common in the universe and is also a p-block element of group IV, lying directly below carbon in the periodic table of elements, so that much of its basic chemistry is similar. For instance, just as carbon combines with four hydrogen atoms to form methane, CH4, silicon yields silane, SiH4. Silicates are analogs of carbonates, silicon chloroform of chloroform, and so on. Both elements form long chains, or polymers, in which they alternate with oxygen. In the simplest case, carbon-oxygen chains yield polyacetal, a plastic used in synthetic fibers, while from a backbone of alternating atoms of silicon and oxygen come polymeric silicones.
 
 Conceivably, some strange life-forms might be built from silicone-like substances were it not for an apparently fatal flaw in silicon's biological credentials. This is its powerful affinity for oxygen. When carbon is oxidized during the respiratory process of a terrestrial organism (see respiration), it becomes the gas carbon dioxide – a waste material that is easy for a creature to remove from its body. The oxidation of silicon, however, yields a solid because, immediately upon formation, silicon dioxide organizes itself into a lattice in which each silicon atom is surrounded by four oxygens. Disposing of such a substance would pose a major respiratory challenge.
 
 Life-forms must also be able to collect, store, and utilize energy from their environment. In carbon-based biota, the basic energy storage compounds are carbohydrates in which the carbon atoms are linked by single bonds into a chain. A carbohydrate is oxidized to release energy (and the waste products water and carbon dioxide) in a series of controlled steps using enzymes. These enzymes are large, complex molecules (see proteins) which catalyze specific reactions because of their shape and "handedness." A feature of carbon chemistry is that many of its compounds can take right and left forms, and it is this handedness, or chirality, that gives enzymes their ability to recognize and regulate a huge variety of processes in the body. Silicon's failure to give rise to many compounds that display handedness makes it hard to see how it could serve as the basis for the many interconnected chains of reactions needed to support life.
 
 The absence of silicon-based biology, or even silicon-based prebiotic chemicals, is also suggested by astronomical evidence. Wherever astronomers have looked – in meteorites, in comets, in the atmospheres of the giant planets, in the interstellar medium, and in the outer layers of cool stars – they have found molecules of oxidized silicon (silicon dioxide and silicates) but no substances such as silanes or silicones which might be the precursors of a silicon biochemistry.
 
 Even so, it has been pointed out, silicon may have had a part to play in the origin of life on Earth. A curious fact is that terrestrial life-forms utilize exclusively right-handed carbohydrates and left-handed amino acids. One theory to account for this is that the first prebiotic carbon compounds formed in a pool of "primordial soup" on a silica surface having a certain handedness. This handedness of the silicon compound determined the preferred handedness of the carbon compounds now found in terrestrial life. An entirely different possibility is that of artificial life or intelligence with a significant silicon content.
